DIV1.P: As it is Performed at the THEATRE in the HAY-MARKET.
LONDON, Printed for G. KEARSLY, opposite St. Martin's Church, in Ludgate-Street. 1764.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: WHAT various revolutions in our art,
Since Thespis first sung ballads in a cart!
By nature fram'd the witty war to wage,
And lay the deep foundations of the stage,
From his own soil that bard his pictures drew:
The gaping crowd the mimic features knew,
And the broad jest with fire electric flew.
Succeeding times, more polish'd and refin'd,
To rigid rules the comic muse confin'd:
Robb'd of the nat'ral freedom of her song,
In artful measures now she floats along;
No sprightly sallies rouse the slumb'ring pit;
Thalia, grown mere architect in wit,
To doors and ladders has confin'd her cares,
Convenient closets, and a snug back-stairs;
'Twixt her and Satire has dissolv'd the league,
And jilted humour to enjoy intrigue.
To gain the suff'rage of this polish'd age,
We bring to-night a stranger on the stage:
His sire De Vega; we confess this truth,
Lest you mistake him for a British youth.
Severe the censure on my feeble pen,
Neglecting manners, that she copies men:
Thus, if I hum or ha, or name report,
'Tis Serjeant Splitcause from the inns of court;
If, at the age that ladies cease to dance,
To romp at Ranelagh, or read romance,
I draw a dowager inclin'd to man,
Or paint her rage for china or japan,
The true original is quickly known,
And Lady Squab proclaim'd throughout the town.
But in the following group let no man dare
To claim a limb, nay, not a single hair:
What gallant Briton can be such a sot
To own the child a Spaniard has begot.

SP.SPEAKER: Young Wilding.
SP.P: AND I am now, Papillion, perfectly equipp'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Papillion.
SP.P: Personne mieux. Nobody better.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: My figure?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Fait a peindre.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: My air?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Libre.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: My address?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Parisiene.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: My hat sits easily under my arm; not like the draggled tail of my tatter'd acade∣mical habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Ah, bien autre chose.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why then, adieu, Alma Mater, and bien venüe, la ville de Londre; farewel to the schools, and welcome the theatres; presidents, proctors, short commons with long graces, must now give place to plays, bagnios, long tavern∣bills with no graces at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Ah, bravo, bravo!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well but, my dear Papillion, you must give me the chart du paye: This town is a new world to me; my provident papa, you know, would never suffer me near the smoak of London; and what can be his motive for per∣mitting me now, I can't readily conceive.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Ni moi.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I shall, however, take the liberty to conceal my arrival from him for a few days.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Vous avez raison.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well, my Mentor, and how am I to manage? direct my road: where must I begin? but the debate is, I suppose, of consequence?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Vraiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: How long have you left Paris, Pa∣pillion?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Twelve, dirteen year.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I can't compliment you upon your progress in English.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: The accent is difficult.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But here you are at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: C'est vrai.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No strangers to fashionable places.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: O faite!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Acquainted with the fashionable figures of both sexes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Sans doute.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well then, open your lecture: And, d'ye hear, Papillion, as you have the honour to be promoted from the mortifying condition of an humble valet, to the important charge of a private tutor, let us discard all distance between us: See me ready to slack my thirst at your fountain of knowledge, my Magnus Apollo.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Here then I disclose my Helicon to my poetical pupil.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Hey, Papillion!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What is this? why, you speak English!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Without doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But like a native!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: To be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: And what am I to conclude from all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Logically thus, Sir: Whoever speaks pure English is an Englishman: I speak pure English; ergo, I am an Englishman. There's a categorical fyllogism for you, Major, Minor, and Consequence. What, do you think, Sir, that whilst you was busy at Oxford, I was idle? no, no, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well, Sir, but notwithstanding your pleasantry, I must have this matter explain'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: So you shall, my good Sir; but don't be in such a hurry: You can't suppose I would give you the key, unless I meant you should open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why then, prythee, unlock.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Immediately. But, by way of entering upon my post as preceptor, suffer me first to give you a hint: You must not expect, Sir, to find here, as at Oxford, men appearing in their real characters; every body there, Sir, knows that Dr. Mussy is a fellow of Maudlin, and Tom Trifle a student of Christchurch; but this town is one great comedy, in which not only the prin∣ciples, but frequently the persons are feign'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A useful observation.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P:
Why now, Sir, at the first coffee-house I shall enter you, you will perhaps meet a man from whose decent sable dress, placid counte∣nance, insinuating behaviour, short sword, with the waiter's civil addition of "a dish of coffee
for Dr. Julap," you would suppose him to be a physician.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Does not know diascordium from dia∣culum. An absolute French spy, conceal'd un∣der the shelter of a huge medicinal perriwig.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: A martial figure too, it is odds but you will encounter; from whose sears, title, dress, and address, you would suppose to have had a share in every action since the peace of the Py∣renees: runner to a gaming-table, and bully to a bawdy-house. Battles, to be sure, he has been in—with the watch; and frequently a prisoner too—in the round-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Amazing!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: In short, Sir, you will meet with lawyers who practise smuggling, and merchants who trade upon Hounslow-heath; reverend atheists, righ honourable sharpers; and Frenchmen fom the county of York.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: In the last list, I presume, you roll.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Just my situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: And pray, Sir, what may be your for this whmsical transformation?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: A very harmless one, I promise you: I would only avail myself at the expence of folly and prjuice.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: As how?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Why, Sir—But, to be better under∣stood, I believe it will be necessary to give you a short sketch of the principal incidents of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Prithee do.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P:
Why then you are to know, Sir, that my former situation has been rather above my present condition, having once sustained the dig∣nity of sub-preceptor to one of those cheap rural
academies with which our county of York is so plentifully stock'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But to the point: Why this disguise? why renounce your country?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: There, Sir, you make a little mistake; it was my country that renounc'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Explain.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: In an instant, upon quitting the school, and first coming to town, I got recommended to the compiler of the Monthly Review.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What, an author too?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Oh, a voluminous one: the whole re∣gion of the belles lettres fell under my inspec∣tion; physic, divinity, and the mathematics, my mistress manag'd herself. There, Sir, like an∣other Aristarch, I dealt out fame and damnation at pleasure. In obedience to the caprice and commands of my master, I have condemn'd books I never read, and applauded the fidelity of a translation, without understanding one syllable of the original.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Ay! why I thought acuteness of dis∣cernment, and depth of knowledge, were ne∣cessary to accomplish a critic.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; but not a monthly one. Our method was very concise: We copy the title∣page of a new book; we never go any further: if we are order'd to praise it, we have at hand about ten words, which, scatter'd through as many periods, effectually does the business; as, "laudable design, happy arrangement, spirited language, nervous sentiment, elevation of thought, conclusive argument;" if we are to decry, then we have, "unconnected, flat, false, illiberal stric∣ture, reprehensible, unnatural:" and thus, Sir, we pepper the author, and soon rid our hands of his work.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A short recipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And yet, Sir, you have all the materials that are necessary: These are the arms with which we engage authors of every kind. To us all subjects are equal; plays or sermons, poetry or politics, music or midwifry, it is the same thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: How came you to resign this easy employment?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: It would not answer. Notwithstanding what we say, people will judge for themselves; our work hung upon hand, and all I could get from the publisher was four shillings a-week, and my small beer. Poor pittance!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Poor indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Oh, half-starv'd me!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What was your next change?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I was mightily puzzled to choose. Some would have had me turn player, and others me∣thodist preacher; but as I had no money to build me a tabernacle, I did not think it could answer; and as to a player—whatever might happen to me, I was determin'd not to bring a disgrace upon my family, and so I resolv'd to turn footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Wisely resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, but not so easily executed.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Oh no, Sir. Many a weary step have I taken after a place: here I was too old, there I was too young; here the last livery was too big, there it was too little; here I was aukward, there I was knowing; madam dissik'd me at this house, her ladyship's woman at the next: So that I was as much puzzled to find out a place, as the great Cynic philosopher to discover a man. In short, I was quite in a state of despair, when Chance threw an old friend in my way that quite retriev'd my affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Pray who might he be?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: A little bit of a Swiss genius, who had been French usher with me at the same school in the country. I open'd my melancholy story to him, over three pennyworth of beef-a la∣mode, in a cellar in St. Ann's. My little foreign friend purs'd up his lanthorn jaws, and with a shrug of contempt, "Ah, maître Jean, vous n'avez pas la politique; you have no finesse: to trive here you must study the folly of your own country." "How, Monsieur!" "Taisez vous. Keep a your tongue! autre foy! I teach you speak French, now I teach a you to forget Eng∣lish. Go vid me to my logement, I vil give you proper dress; den go present yourself to de same hotels, de very same house; you will find all de doors dat was shut in your face as footman An∣glois, will fly open demselves to a French valet de chambre."

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well, Papillion?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Gad, Sir, I thought it was but an ho∣nest artifice, so I determin'd to follow my friend's advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Did it succeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Better than expectation: my tawny face, long queüe, and broken English, was a pas par tout. Besides, when I am out of place, this disguise procures me many resources.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: As how?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Why, at a pinch, Sir, I am either a teacher of tongues, a frizeur, a dentist, or a dancing-master; these, Sir, are hereditary profes∣sions to Frenchmen. But now, Sir, to the point: As you were pleas'd to be so candid with me, I was determin'd to have no reserve with you. You have study'd books, I have study'd men; you want advice, and I have some at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well, I'll be your customer.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: But guard my secret: if I should be so unfortunate to lose your place, don't shut me out from every other.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You may rely upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: In a few years I shall be in a condition to retire from business; but whether I shall set∣tle at my family-seat, or pass over to the conti∣nent, is as yet undetermined. Perhaps, in gra∣titude to the country, I may purchase a marqui∣sate near Paris, and spend the money I have got by their means, generously amongst them.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A grateful intention. But let us sally. Where do we open?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Let us see—one o'clock—it is a fine day: the Mall will be crowded.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Alons.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: But don't stare, Sir: survey every thing with an air of habit and indifference.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: But I would, Sir, crave a moment's au∣dience, upon a subject that may prove very ma∣terial to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: You will pardon my presumption; but you have, my good master, one little foible that I could wish you to correct.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And yet it is a pity too, you do it so very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Prithee be plain.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: You have, Sir, a lively imagination, with a most happy turn for invention.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: But now and then in your narratives you are hurry'd, by a flow of spirits, to border upon the improbable, a little given to the marvellous.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I understand you: what, I am some∣what subject to lying.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Oh, pardon me, Sir; I don't say that; no, no: only a little apt to embellish; that's all. To be sure it is a fine gift; that there is no dis∣puting: but men in general are so stupid; so ri∣gorously attach'd to matter of fact—And yet this talent of yours is the very soul and spirit of poetry; and why it should not be the same in prose, I can't for my life determine.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You would advise me, then, not to be quite so poetical in my prose?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Why, Sir, if you would descend a little to the grovelling comprehension of the million, I think it would be as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I'll think of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Besides, Sir, in this town people are more smoaky and suspicious. Oxford, you know, is the seat of the muses, and a man is naturally permitted more ornament and garniture to his conversation than they will allow in this latitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I believe you are right. But we shall be late. D'ye hear me, Papillion: if at any time you find me growing too poetical, give me a hint; your advice shan't be thrown away.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I wish it mayn't; but the disease is too rooted to be quickly remov'd. Lord, how I have sweat for him! yet he is as unimbarrassed, easy, and fluent, all the time, as if he really be∣liev'd what he said. Well, to be sure he is a great master; it is a thousand pities his genius could not be converted to some public service: I think the government should employ him to answer the Brussels Gazette. I'll be hang'd if he is not too many for Monsieur Maubert, at his own weapons.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the Park.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Miss GRANTHAM and Miss GODFREY, and Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Grantham.
SP.P: John, let the chariot go round to Spring-Gardens, for your mistress and I shall call at Lady Bab's, Miss Arabella Allnight's, the countess of Crumple's, and the tall man's, this morning. My dear Miss Godfrey, what trouble I have had to get you out! why, child, you are as tedious as a long mourning. Do you know now, that of all places of public rendezvous I honour the Park? forty thousand million of times preferable to the play-house! Don't you think so, my dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Godfrey.
SP.P: They are both well in their way.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Way! why the purpose of both is the same; to meet company, i'n't it? what, d'ye think I go there for the plays, or come here for the trees? ha. ha! well, that is well enough. But, O Gemini! I beg a million of pardons: You are a prude, and have no relish for the lit∣tle innocent liberties with which a fine woman may indulge herself in public.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Liberties in public!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Yes, child; such as encoring a song at an opera, interrupting a play in a critical scene of distress, hallowing to a pretty fellow cross the Mall, as loud as if you were calling a coach. Why, do you know now, my dear, that luky stroke in dress, and a few high airs making, I have had the good at and followed by as great a I was the Tripoli ▪

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: The good fortune, Ma'am! Surely, the wish of every decent woman is to be unno∣tic'd in public.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Decent! oh, my dear queer creature, what a phrase have you found out for a woman of fashion! Decency is, child, a mere bourgois plebeian quality, and fit only for those who pay court to the world, and not for us to whom the world pays court. Upon my word, you must enlarge your ideas: you are a fine girl, and we must not have you lost; I'll undertake you my∣self. But, as I was saying—Pray, my dear, what was I saying?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I profess I don't recollect.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Hey!—Oh, ay, the park. One great reason for my loving the Park is, that one has so many opportunities of creating connections.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Nay, don't look grave. Why, do you know that all my male friendships are form'd in this place?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: It is an odd spot: But you must par∣don me if I doubt the possibility.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh, I will convince you in a moment; for here seems to be coming a good smart figure that I don't recollect. I will throw out a lure.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Nay, for Heaven's sake!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I am determin'd, child: that is—

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: You will excuse my withdrawing.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh, please yourself, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Your ladyship's handkerchief, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I am, Sir, concern'd at the trouble—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P:
A most happy incident for me, Ma∣dam; as Chance has given me an honour in one
lucky minute, that the most diligent attention has not been able to procure for me in the whole tedious round of a revolving year.

SP.SPEAKER: M Gr.
SP.P: Is this meant to me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: To whom else, Madam? Surely, you must have mark'd my respectful assiduity, my uninterrupted attendance; to plays, operas, balls, routs, and ridottas, I have pursued you like your shadow; I have besieg'd your door for a glimpse of your exit and entrance, like a dis∣tressed creditor, who has no arms against privi∣lege but perseverance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: So, now he is in for it; stop him who can.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: In short, Madam, ever since I quit∣ted America, which I take now to be about a year, I have as faithfully guarded, the live-long night, your ladyship's portal, as a centinel the powder-magazine in a fortified city.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Quitted America! well pull'd.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: You have serv'd in America then?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Full four years, Ma'am: and during that whole time, not a single action of conse∣quence, but I had an opportunity to signalize myself; and I think I may, without vanity, af∣firm I did not miss the occasion. You have heard of Quebec, I presume?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: What the deuce is he driving at now?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The project to surprize that place was thought a happy expedient, and the first mounting the breach a gallant exploit. There, indeed, the whole army did me justice.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I have heard the honour of that con∣quest attributed to another name.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P:
The mere taking the town, Ma'am. But that's a trifle: Sieges now a-days are re∣duc'd to certainties; it is amazing how mi∣nutely
exact we, who know the business, are at calculation: For instance now, we will suppose the commander in chief, addressing himself to me, was to say, "Colonel, I want to reduce that fortress; what will be the expence?" "Why, please your highness, the reduction of that fortress will cost you one thousand and two lives, sixty-nine legs, ditto arms, fourscore frac∣tures, with about twenty dozen of flesh wounds."

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: And you should be near the mark?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: To an odd joint, Ma'am. But, Ma∣dam, it is not to the French alone that my feats are confin'd: Cherokees, Catabaws, with all the Aws and Ees of the continent, have felt the force of my arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: This is too much, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Hands off! Nor am I less adroit at a treaty, Madam, than terrible in battle: To me we owe the friendship of the Five Nations, and I had the first honour of smoaking the pipe of peace with the Little Carpenter.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: And so young!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: This gentleman, though a French∣man and an enemy, I had the fortune to deli∣ver from the Mohawks, whose prisoner he had been for nine years. He gives a most enter∣taining account of their laws and customs: he shall present you with the wampum-belt, and a scalping-knife. Will you permit him, Madam, just to give you a taste of the military-dance, with a short specimen of their warhoop?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: The place is too public.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P:
In short, Madam, after having ga∣thered as many laurels abroad as would garnish a Gothic cathedral at Christmas, I returned to reap the harvest of the well-fought field. Here
it was my good fortune to encounter you: then was the victor vanquished; what the enemy could never accomplish, your eyes in an instant atchiev'd; prouder to serve here than command in chief elsewhere; and more glorious in wear∣ing your chains, than in triumphing over the vanquish'd world.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I have got here a most heroical lover: But If ames Elliot coming, and must dis∣miss hi. [side] Well, Sir, I accept the ten∣dre of your passion, nd may find a time to re∣new our acquaintac, at present it is necessary we should separa.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: " to your will, I live but to obey you." I be indulg'd with the knowledge ur residence.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Your place of abode?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh Sir, you can't want to be ac∣quainted with that; you who have a whole year stood centinel at my ladyship's portal.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Madam, I—I—I—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, your servant. Ha, ha, ha! What, you are caught! Ha, ha, ha! Well, he has a most intrepid assurance. Adieu, my Mars. Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: That last was an unlucky question, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A little mal-a-propos, I must confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: A man should have a good memory who deals much in this poetical prose.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Poh! I'll soon re-establish my cre∣dit. But I must know who this girl is: Hark ye, Papillion, could not you contrive to pump out of her footman—I see there he stands—the name of his mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I will try.
SP.STAGE: [Wilding retires to the back of the stage.
Enter Sir JAMES ELLIOT, and Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir James.
SP.P: Music and an entertainment?

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Last night, upon the water?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Upon the water, last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Who gave it?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: That, Sir, I can't say.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir James Elliot, your most devoted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Ah, my dear Wilding! you are wel∣come to town.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You will pardon my impatience; I interrupted you; you seem'd upon an interesting subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Oh, an affair of gallantry.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Of what kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: A young lady regal'd last night by her lover, on the Thames.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: As how?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: A band of music in boats.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Were they good performers?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: The best. Then conducted to Marble-hall, where she found a magnificent collation.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well order'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: With elegance. After supper a ball; and, to conclude the night, a firework.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Was the last well design'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Superb.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: And happily executed?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Not a single faux pas.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: And you don't know who gave it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: I can't even guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Wild
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Why do you laugh?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! It was me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: You!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: You, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Moi—me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: So, so, so; he is enter'd again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Why, you are fortunate, to find a mis∣tress in so short a space of time.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Short! why, man, I have been in London these six weeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: O Lord, O Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: It is true, not caring to encounter my father, I have rarely ventur'd out but at nights.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I can hold no longer. Dear Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Peace, puppy!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: A curb to your poetical vein.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I shall curb your impertinence.—But since the story is got abroad I will, my dear friend, treat you with all the particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I shall hear it with pleasure.—This is a lucky adventure: but he must not know he is my rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, Sir, between six and seven my goddess imbark'd, at Somerset-stairs, in one of the companies barges, gilt and hung with da∣mask, expresly for the occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Mercy on us!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: At the cabin-door she was accosted by a beautiful boy, who, in the garb of a Cu∣pid, paid her some compliments in verse of my own composing: The conceits were pretty; allu∣sions to Venus and the sea—the lady and the Thames—no great matter; but, however, well∣tim'd, and, what was better, well taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Doubtless.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap
SP.P: At what a rate he runs!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P:
As soon as we had gain'd the center of the river, two boats, full of trumpets, French
horns, and other martial music, struck up their sprightly strains from the Surry-side, which were eccho'd by a suitable number of lutes, flutes, and hautboys, from the opposite shore. In this state, the oars keeping time, we majestically sail'd along, till the arches of the New Bridge gave a pause, and an opportunity for an elegant desert in Dresden-china, by Robinson. Here the repast clos'd, with a few favourite airs from Eliza, Tenducci, and the Mattei.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Mercy on us!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Opposite Lambeth I had prepar'd a naval engagement, in which Boscawen's victory over the French was repeated: the action was conducted by one of the commanders on that expedition, and not a single incident omitted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Surely you exaggerate a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Yes, yes, this battle will sink him.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: True to the letter, upon my honour. I sha'n't trouble you with the repetition of our collation, ball, feu d'artifice, with the thousand little incidental amusements that chance or de∣sign produc'd: it is enough to know, that all that could flatter the senses, fire the imagination, or gratify the expectation, was there produc'd in a lavish abundance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: The sacrifice was, I presume, grateful to your deity.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Upon that subject you must pardon my silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Modest creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I wish you joy of your success.—For the present you will excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Nay, but stay and hear the conclusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: For that I shall seize another occa∣sion.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Nobly perform'd, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Yes, I think happily hit off.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: May I take the liberty to offer one question?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, are you often visited with these waking dreams?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Dreams! what dost mean by dreams?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: These ornamental reveries, these frolics of fancy, which, in the judgment of the vul∣gar, would be deem'd absolute flames.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, Papillion, you have but a poor, narrow, circumscribed genius.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I must own, Sir, I have not sublimity sufficient to relish the full fire of your Pindaric muse.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No; a plebeian soul! But I will ani∣mate thy clay: mark my example, follow my steps, and in time thou may'st rival thy master.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Never, never, Sir: I have not talents to fight battles without blows, and give feasts that don't cost me a farthing. Besides, Sir, to what purpose are all these embellishments? why tell the lady you have been in London a year?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The better to plead the length, and consequently strength of my passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: But why, Sir, a soldier?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: How little thou know'st of the sex! What, I suppose thou wouldst have me attack them in mood and figure, by a pedantic, clas∣sical quotation, or a pompous parade of jargon from the schools. What, dost think that women are to be got like degrees!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Nay, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P:
No, no; the savoir vivre is the sci∣ence for them; the man of war is their man: they must be taken like towns, by lines of ap∣proach, counterscarps, angles, trenches, cohorns,
and covert-ways; then enter sword in hand, pell-mell: oh, how they melt at the Gothic names of General Swappinback, Count Rousoumousky, Prince Montecuculi, and Marshal Fustinburgh! Men may say what they will of their Ovid, their Petrarch, and their Waller, but I'll undertake to do more business by the single aid of the London Gazette, than by all the sighing, dying, crying crotchets, that the whole race of rhymers have ever produc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Very well, Sir; this is all very lively; but remember the travelling pitcher: if you don't one time or other, under favour, lye your∣self into some confounded scrape, I will be con∣tent to be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Do you think so, Papillion?—And whenever that happens, if I don't lye myself out of it again, why then I will be content to be crucify'd. And so, along after the lady. [Stops short, going out.] Zounds, here comes my father! I must fly. Watch him, Papillion, and bring me word to the Cardigan.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE a Tavern.
DIV3.STAGE: YOUNG WILDING and PAPILLION rising from Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Young Wilding.
SP.P: GAD, I had like to have run into the old gentleman's mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: It is pretty near the same thing; for I saw him join Sir James Elliot: so your arrival is no longer a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why then I must lose my pleasure, and you your preferment: I must submit to the dull decency of a sober family, and you to the customary duties of brushing and powder∣ing. But I was so flutter'd at meeting my fa∣ther, that I forgot the fair: prythee who is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: There were two.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: That I saw?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: From her footman I learnt her name was Godfrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: And her fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Immense.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Single, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Then will I have her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: What, whether she will or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: How will you manage that?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: By making it impossible for her to marry any body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I don't understand you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, I shall only have recourse to that talent you so mightily admire. You will see, by the circulation of a few anecdotes, how soon I will get rid of my rivals.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: At the expence of the lady's reputation, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: That will be as it happens.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And have you no qualms, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, where's the injury?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: No injury to ruin her fame!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I will restore it to her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Turn tinker, and mend it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Which way?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The old way; solder it by marriage: that, you know, is the modern salve for every sore.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: An elderly gentleman to enquire for Mr. Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: For me! what sort of a being is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Being, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Ay; how is he drest?

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: In a tye-wig and snuff-colour'd coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Zooks, Sir, it is your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Shew him up.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And what must I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Recover your broken English, but preserve your rank: I have a reason for it.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Your servant, Sir: you are welcome to town.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You have just prevented me, Sir: I was preparing to pay my duty to you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: If you thought it a duty, you should, I think, have sooner discharg'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Was it quite so decent, Jack, to be six weeks in town, and conceal yourself only from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Six weeks! I have scarce been six hours.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Come, come; I am better inform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, you are impos'd upon. This gentleman (whom first give me leave to have the honour of introducing to you), this, Sir, is the marquis de Chatteau Briant, of an ancient house in Brittany; who travelling thro' England, chose to make Oxford for some time the place of his residence, where I had the hap∣piness of his acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Does he speak English?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Not fluently, but understands it per∣fectly.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Pray, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Any services, Sir, that I can render you here you may readily command.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Beaucoup d'honeur.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: This gentleman, I say, Sir, whose quality and country are sufficient securities for his veracity, will assure you that yesterday we left Oxford together.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: C'est vrai.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: This is amazing. I was, at the same time, inform'd of another circumstance too, that, I confess, made me a little uneasy, as it interfer'd with a favourite scheme of my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What could that be, pray, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: That you had conceiv'd a violent af∣fection for a fair lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And had given her very gallant and very expensive proofs of your passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Me, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Particularly last night; music, colla∣tions, balls, and fireworks.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Monsieur le marquis!—And pray, Sir, who could tell you all this?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: An old friend of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: His name, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Sir James Elliot.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Yes; I thought he was the man.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Your reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, Sir, though Sir James Elliot has a great many good qualities, and is, upon the whole, a valuable man, yet he has one fault which has long determined me to drop his ac∣quaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What may that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why you can't, Sir, be a stranger to his prodigious skill in the traveller's talent.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, notorious to a proverb.—His friends, who are tender of his fame, gloss over his foible, by calling him an agreeable novelist; and so he is, with a vengeance: Why, he will tell you more lyes in an hour, than all the cir∣culating libraries, put together, will publish in a year.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, he is the modern Mandeville at Oxford: he was always distinguish'd by the fa∣cetious appellation of the Bouncer.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Amazing!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, he is so well understood in his own country, that at the last Hereford assize a cause, as clear as the sun, was absolutely thrown away by his being merely mentioned as a witness.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: A strange turn.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Unaccountable. But there, I think, they went a little too far; for if it had come to an oath, I don't think he would have bounc'd neither; but in common occurrences there is no repeating after him. Indeed, my great reason for dropping him was, that my credit began to be a little suspected too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Poor gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why, I never heard this of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: That may be: but can there be a stronger proof of his practice than the flam he has been telling you, of fireworks, and the Lord knows what. And I dare swear, Sir, he was very fluent and florid in his description.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Extremely.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Yes, that is just his way; and not a syllable of truth from the beginning to the end∣ing, marquis?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Oh, dat is all a fiction, upon mine honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You see, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Clearly. I really can't help pitying the poor man. I have heard of people, who, by long habit, become a kind of constitutional lyars.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Your observation is just; that is ex∣actly his case.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I'm sure it is yours.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Well; Sir, I suppose we shall see you this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The marquis has an appointment with some of his countrymen, which I have promis'd to attend; besides, Sir, as he is an entire stranger in town, he may want my little services.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Where can I see you in about an hour? I have a short visit to make, in which you are deeply concern'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I shall attend your commands; but where?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why here. Marquis, I am your obedient servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Votre serviteur tres humble.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: So, Papillion; that difficulty is dis∣patch'd. I think I am even with Sir James for his tattling.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Most ingeniously manag'd: But are not you afraid of the consequence?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: I don't comprehend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: A future explanation between the par∣ties.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: That may embarrass: but the day is distant. I warrant I will bring myself off.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: It is in vain for me to advise.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, to say truth, I do begin to find my system attended with danger: Give me your hand, Papillion—I will reform.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Ah, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I positively will: Why this practice may in time destroy my credit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: That is pretty well done already. [Aside.] Ay, think of that, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well, if I don't turn out the meerest dull matter of fact fellow—But, Papillion, I must scribble a billet to my new flame. I think her name is—

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Godfrey; her father, an India governor shut up in the strong room in Calcutta, left her all his wealth: she lives near Miss Grantam, by Grosvenor-square.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A governor!—oh ho!—Bushels of rupees, and pecks of pagodas, I reckon.—Well, I long to be rummaging.—But the old gentleman will soon return: I will hasten to finish my letter.—But, Papillion, what could my father mean by a visit in which I am deeply concern'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I can't guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I shall know presently.—To Miss Godfrey, formerly of Calcutta, now residing in Grosvenor-square.—Papillion, I won't tell her a word of a lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: You won't, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No; it would be ungenerous to de∣ceive a lady. No; I will be open, candid, and sincere.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And if you are, it will be the first me.
SP.STAGE: Enter Miss GRANTAM and Miss GODFREY.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: And you really like this gallant spark?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Prodigiously. Oh, I'm quite in love with his assurance! I wonder who he is: he can't have been long in town: a young fellow of his easy impudence must have soon made his way to the best company.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: By way of amusement he may prove no disagreeable acquaintance; but you can't, surely, have any serious designs upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Indeed but I have.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: And poor Sir James Elliot is to be discarded at once?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh, no.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: What is your intention in regard to him?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Hey?—I can't tell you. Perhaps, if I don't like this new man better, I may marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Thou art a strange giddy girl.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Quite the reverse; a perfect pattern of prudence: why, would you have me less careful of my person than my purse?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: My dear!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Why I say, child, my fortune being in money, I have some in India-bonds, some in the Bank, some on this loan, some on the other; so that if one fund fails, I have a sure resource in the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Very true.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Well, my dear, just so I manage my love-affairs: if I should not like this man—if he should not like me—if we should quarrel—if, if—or in short, if any of the ifs should hap∣pen, which you know break engagements every day, why by this means I shall be never at a loss.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Quite provident. Well, and pray on how many different securities have you at present plac'd out your love?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Three: the sober Sir James Elliot, the new America-man, and this morning I ex∣pect a formal proposal from an old friend of my father.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Mr. Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P:
Yes; but I don't reckon much upon him: for you know, my dear, what can I do with an aukward, raw, college cub? Though,
upon second thoughts, that mayn't be too bad neither; for as I must have the fashioning of him, he may be easily moulded to one's mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Wilding, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Shew him in. [Exit Servant.] You need not go, my dear; we have no particular business.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I wonder now what she calls parti∣cular business.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Ladies, your servant. I wait upon you, Madam, with a request from my son, that he may be permitted the honour of kissing your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Your son is in town, then?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: He came last night, Ma'am; and though but just from the university. I think I may venture to affirm, with as little the air of a pedant as—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I don't, Mr. Wilding, question the accomplishments of your son; and shall own too, that his being descended from the old friend of my father, is to me the strongest re∣commendation.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You honour me, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: But, Sir, I have something to say—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, speak out; it is im∣possible to be too explicit on these important occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr
SP.P:
Why then, Sir, to a man of your wis∣dom and experience I need not observe, that the loss of a parent to counsel and direct at this so∣lemn
crisis, has made a greater degree of per∣sonal prudence necessary in me.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Perfectly right, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: We live, Sir, in a very censorious world: a young woman can't be too much upon her guard; nor should I chuse to admit any man in the quality of a lover, if there was not at least a strong probability—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Of a more intimate connection. I hope, Madam, you have heard nothing to the disadvantage of my son.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Not a syllable: but you know, Sir, there are such things in nature as unaccountable antipathies, aversions, that we take at first sight: I should be glad there could be no dan∣ger of that.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I understand you, Madam; you shall have all the satisfaction imaginable: Jack is to meet me immediately; I will conduct him under your window; and if his figure has the misfortune to displease, I will take care his ad∣dresses shall never offend you. Your most obe∣dient servant.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Now there is a polite, sensible, old father for you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Yes; and a very discreet, prudent daughter he is likely to have. Oh, you are a great hypocrite, Kitty.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: A letter for you, Madam. [To Miss Godfrey.] Sir James Elliot to wait on your la∣dyship. [To Miss Grantam.]

SP.SPEAKER: M. Cr.
SP.P: Lord, I hope he won't stay long here. He comes, and seems entirely wrapt up in the dismals: what can be the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: In passing by your door, I took the liberty, Ma'am, of enquiring after your health.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Very obliging. I hope, Sir, you re∣ceiv'd a favourable account.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I did not know but you might have caught cold last night.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Cold! why, Sir, I hope I did not sleep with my bed-chamber window open.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: No, Ma'am; but it was rather ha∣zardous to stay so late upon the water.

SP.SPEAKER: M Gr.
SP.P: Upon the water!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Not but the variety of amusements, it must be own'd, were a sufficient temptation.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: What can he be driving at now!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: And pray, Madam, what think you of Young Wilding? it not he a gay, agreeable, sprightly—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I never give my opinion of people I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: You don't know him!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: And his father I did not meet at your door!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Most likely you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I am glad you own that, however: But, for the son, you never—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Sat eyes upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Really?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Really.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Finely supported. Now, Madam, do you know that one of us is just going to make a very ridiculous figure?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Sir, I never had the least doubt of your talents for excelling in that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Ma'am, you do me honour: but it does not happen to fall to my lot upon this oc∣casion, however.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: And that is a wonder!—What, then, I am to be the fool of the comedy, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Admirably rally'd! But I shall dash the spirit of that triumphant laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I dare the attack. Come on, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Know then, and blush, if you are not as lost to shame as dead to decency, that I am no stranger to all last night's transactions.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: From your first entering the barge at Somerset-house, to your last landing at White-hall.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Surprizing!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Cupids, collations, feasts, fireworks, all have reach'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Why you must deal in magic.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: My intelligence is as natural as it is infallible.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: May I be indulg'd with the name of your informer?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Freely, Madam. Only the very indi∣vidual spark to whose folly you were indebted for this gallant profusion.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: But his name?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Young Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: You had this story from him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I had.

SP.SPEAKER: M Gr.
SP.P: From Wilding!—That is amazing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Oh ho! what you are confounded at last; and no evasion, no subtersuge, no—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P:
Lookye, Sir James; what you can mean by this strange story, and very extraordi∣nary
behaviour, it is impossible for me to con∣ceive; but if it is meant as an artifice to palli∣ate your infidelity to me, less pains would have answer'd your purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, I know you are pro∣vided.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Matchless insolence! As you can't expect that I should be prodigiously pleas'd with the subject of this visit, you won't be surpriz'd at my wishing it as short as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I don't wonder you feel pain at my presence; but you may rest secure: you will have no interruption for me; and I really think it would be pity to part two people so exactly form'd for each other. Your ladyship's servant. [Going.] But, Madam, though your sex secures you from any farther resentment, yet the present object of your favour may have something to fear.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Very well. Now, my dear, I hope you will acknowledge the prudence of my plan. To what a pretty condition I must have been reduc'd if my hopes had rested upon one lover alone!

SP.SPEAKER: M God.
SP.P: But are you sure that your method to multiply, may not be the means to reduce the number of your slaves?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Impossible!—Why, can't you discern that this flam of Sir James Elliot's is a mere fetch to favour his retreat?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: And you never saw Wilding?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: There is some mystery in this. I have too here in my hand another mortification that you must endure.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Of what kind?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: A little ally'd to the last: it is from the military spark you met this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: What are the contents?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Only a formal declaration of love.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Why, you did not see him.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: But it seems he did me.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Might I peruse it?—"Battles—no wounds so fatal—cannon-balls—Cupid—spring a mine—cruelty—die on a counterscarp—eyes—artillery—death—the stranger." It is address'd to you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I told you so.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: You will pardon me, my dear; but I really can't compliment you with the supposition of a conquest at my expence.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: That would be enough to make me vain: But why do you think it is so impossible?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: And do you positively want a reason?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Positively.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Why then I shall refer you for an an∣swer to a faithful counsellor and most accom∣plish'd critic.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Who may that be?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: The mirror upon your toilet.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Perhaps you may differ in judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Why, can glasses flatter?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I can't say I think that necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Saucy enough!—But come, child, don't let us quarrel upon so whimsical an occa∣sion; time will explain the whole. You will fa∣vour me with your opinion of Young Wilding at my window.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P:
You will forgive me, my dear, the little hint I dropt: it was meant merely to serve you; for indeed, child, there is no quality so
insufferable in a young woman as self conceit and vanity.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: You are most prodigiously obliging.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I'll follow you, Miss. [Exit Miss God∣fry] Pert thing!—She grows immoderately ugly: I always thought her aukward, but she is now an absolute fright.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Miss, Miss Grantam, your hero's at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I come.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God
SP.P: As I live, the very individual stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: No sure!—Oh Lord, let me have a pee.

SP.SPEAKER: M God.
SP.P: It is he, it is he, it is he.
SP.STAGE: Enter OLD WILDING, YOUNG WILDING, and PAPILLION.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: There, Marquis, you must pardon me, for though Paris be more compact, yet surely London covers a much greater quantity.—Oh, Jack, look at that corner house; how d'ye like it▪

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Very well: but I don't see any thing extraordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I wish though you were the master of what it contains.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: What may that be, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: The mistress, you rogue you: a fine girl, and an immense fortune; ay, and a prudent sensible wench into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Wild.
SP.P: Time enough yet, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I don't see that: You are, lad, the last of our ra, and I should be glad to see some probability of its continuance.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Suppose, Sir, you were to repeat your endeavours; you have cordially my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: No; rather too late in life for that experiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, Sir, would you recommend a condition to me, that you disapprove of yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why, Sirrah, I have done my duty to the public and my family by producing you: now, Sir, it is incumbent on you to discharge your debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: In the college cant, I shall beg leave to tick a little longer.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why then, to be serious, son, this is the very business I wanted to talk with you about. In a word, I wish you married; and by providing the lady of that mansion for the pur∣pose, I have prov'd myself both a father and a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Far be it from me to question your care; yet some preparation for so important a change—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, I will allow you a week.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A little more knowledge of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: That you may study at leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Now all Europe is in arms, my de∣sign was to serve my country abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You will be full as useful to it by re∣cruiting her subjects at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Y Wild.
SP.P: You are then resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Fix'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Positively?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Peremptorily.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No prayers—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Can move me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: How the deuce shall I get out of this toil. [Aside.] But suppose, Sir, there should be an unsurmountable objection?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, leave the reconciling that to me; I am an excellent casuist.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But I say, Sir, if it should be impos∣sible to obey your commands?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Impossible!—I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, Sir!—But, on my knees, first let me crave your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Pardon! for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I fear I have lost all title to your fu∣ture favour.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Which way?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I have done a deed—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Let us hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: At Abington, in the county of Berks.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I am—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Already married.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Married!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Married!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Married.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And without my consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Compell'd; fatally forc'd. Oh, Sir, did you but know all the circumstances of my sad, sad story, your rage would soon convert it∣self to pity.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What an unlucky event!—But rise, and let me hear it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The shame and confusion I now feel renders that task at present impossible: I must therefore rely for the relation on the good offices of this faithful friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Me, Sir, I never heard one word of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Come, Marquis, favour me with the particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Upon my vard, Sire, dis affair has so shock me, dat I am almost as incapable to tell de tale as your son.—[To Young Wilding.] Dry a your tears. What can I say, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Any thing.—Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: You see, Sire.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Your kind concern at the misfor∣tunes of my family calls for the most grateful acknowledgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Dis is great misfortune, sans doute.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: But if you, a stranger, are thus af∣fected, what must a father feel?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Oh, beaucoup, great deal more.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: But since the evil is without a re∣medy, let us know the worst at once. Well, Sir, at Abington.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Yes, at Abington.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: In the county of Berks.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Dat is right; in de county of Berks.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Ah, Jack, Jack! are all my hopes then—Though I dread to ask, yet it must be known, who is the girl, pray, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: De girl, Sir—[Aside to Young Wilding.] Who shall I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: For de girl, I can't say, upon my vard.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Her condition?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Pas grande condition; dat is to be sure. But dere is no help.—[Aside to Young Wilding.] Sir, I am quite aground.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Yes; I read my shame in his reserve: some artful hussy!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Dat may be. Vat you call hussy?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: Or perhaps some common creature! But I'm prepar'd to hear the worst.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Have you no mercy?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I'll step to your relief, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: O Lord! a happy deliverance.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Though it is almost death for me to speak, yet it would be infamous to let the re∣putation of the lady suffer by my silence: She is, Sir, of an ancient house, and unblemish'd character.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: That is something.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: And though her fortune may not be equal to the warm wishes of a fond father, yet—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: Her name.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Miss Lydia Sybthorpe.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Sybthorpe.—I never heard of the name. But proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The latter end of last long vacation, I went with Sir James Elliot to pass a few days at a new purchase of his nea Abington. There at an assembly it was my chance to meet and dance with this lady.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: Is she handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, more beautiful—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Nay, no raptures; but go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: But to her beauty she adds polite∣ness, affability, and discretion; unless she for∣feited that character by fixing her affection on me.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Modestly observ'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I was deterr'd from a public declara∣tion of my passion, dreading the scantiness of her fortune would prove an objection to you. Some private interviews she permitted.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Was that so decent?—But love and prudence, madness and reason!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: One fatal evening, the twentieth of September, if I mistake not, we were in a re∣tir'd room, innocently exchanging mutual vows, when her father, whom we expected to sup abroad, came suddenly upon us. I had just time to conceal myself in a closet.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What, unobserv'd by him?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Entirely. But, as my ill stars would have it, a cat, of whom my wife is vastly fond, had a few days before lodg'd a litter of kittens in the same place: I unhappily trod upon one of the brood, which so provok'd the implacable mother, that she flew at me with the fury of a tiger.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: I have observ'd those creatures very fierce in defence of their young.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I shall hate a cat as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The noise rous'd the old gentleman's attention: he open'd the door, and there dis∣cover'd your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Unlucky.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I rush'd to the door; but fatally my foot slipt at the top of the stairs, and down I came tumbling to the bottom; the pistol in my hand went off by accident: this alarm'd her three brothers in the parlour, who, with all their servants, rush'd with united force upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And so surpriz'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No, Sir; with my sword I for some time made a gallant defence, and should have inevitably escap'd, but a raw-bon'd, over-grown, clumsy cook-wench, struck at my sword with a kitchen poker, broke it in two, and compell'd me to surrender at discretion: the consequence of which is obvious enough.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Natural. The lady's reputation, your condition, her beauty, your love, all com∣bin'd to make marriage an unavoidable measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: May I hope then you rather think me unfortunate than culpable?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why, your situation is a sufficient excuse: all I blame you for is the keeping it a secret from me. With Miss Grantam I shall make an aukward figure; but the best apology is the truth: I'll hasten and explain it to her all.—Oh, Jack, Jack, this is a mortifying business.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Most melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I am amaz'd, Sir, that you have so carefully conceal'd this transaction from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Heyday! what do you believe it too?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Believe it! Why is not the story of the marriage true?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Not a syllable.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And the cat, and the pistol, and the poker!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: All invention. And were you really taken in?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, how was it possible to avoid it? Mercy on us! what a collection of circum∣stances have you crowded together!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Genius; the meer effect of genius, Papillion. But to deceive you, who so tho∣roughly know me!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: But to prevent that for the future, could not you just give your humble servant a hint, when you are bent upon bouncing. Besides, Sir, if you recollect your fix'd resolution to re∣form—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Ay, as to matter of fancy, the mere sport and frolic of invention: but in case of ne∣cessity—why, Miss Godfrey was at stake, and I was forc'd to use all my finesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Two letters, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: There are two things in my conscience my master will never want: a prompt lie, and a ready excuse for telling of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Hum! business begins to thicken upon us: a challenge from Sir James Elliot, and a rendezvous from the pretty Miss Godfrey. They shall both be observ'd, but in their order; therefore the lady first. Let me see—I have not been twenty hours in town, and I have already got a challenge, a mistress, and a wife; now if I can but get engag'd in a chancery-suit, I shall have my hands pretty full of employment. Come, Papillion, we have no time to be idle.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Godfrey.
SP.P: UPON my word, Miss Grantam, this is but an idle piece of curiosity: you know the man is already dispos'd of and therefore—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: That is true, my dear; but there is in this affair some mystery that I must and will have explain'd.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Come, come, I know the grievance. You can't brook that this spark, though even a married man, should throw off his allegiance to you, and enter a volunteer in my service.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: And so you take the fact for granted?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Have not I his letter?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Conceited creature!—I fancy, Miss, by your vast affection for this letter, it is the first of the kind you have ever receiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Nay, my dear, why should you be piqu'd at me? the fault is none of mine; I dropt no handkerchief; I threw out no lure: the bird came willingly to hand, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Metaphorical too! what, you are set∣ting up for a wit as well as a belle! why really, Madam, to do you justice, you have full as fine pretensions to one as the other.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I fancy, Madam, the world will not form their judgment of either from the report of a disapointed rival.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Rival! admirably rally'd!—But, let me tell you, Madam, this sort of behaviour, Madam, at your own house, whatever may be your beauty, is no great proof of your breed∣ing, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: As to that, Ma'am, I hope I shall al∣ways shew a proper resentment to any insult that is offer'd me, let it be in whose house it will. The assignation, Ma'am, both time and place, was of your own contriving.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Mighty well, Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: But if, dreading a mortification, you think proper to alter your plan, your chair, I believe, is in waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: It is, Madam! then let it wait.—Oh, what that was your scheme! but it won't take, Miss: the contrivance is a little too shallow.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Cunning creature! So all this inso∣lence was concerted, it seems; a plot to drive me out of the house, that you might have the fellow all to yourself: But I have a regard for your character, though you neglect it. Fie, Miss! a passion for a married man! I really blush for you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: And I most sincerely pity you. But curb your choler a little: the enquiry you are about to make requires rather a cooler disposi∣tion of mind; and by this time the hero is at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Mighty well; I am prepar'd. But, Miss Godfrey, if you really wish to be acquitted of all artificial, underhand dealings, in this af∣fair, suffer me in your name to manage the in∣terview.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Most willingly. But he will recol∣lect your voice.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh, that is easily alter'd. [Enter a Maid, who whispers Miss Grantam, and exit.] It is he; but hide yourself, Miss, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Your hood a little forwarder, Miss: you may be known, and then we shall have the language of politeness inflam'd to proofs of a violen passion.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: You are prodigiously cauious.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: This rendezvous is something in the Spanish taste, imported, I suppose, with the guitar. At present I presume, the custom is confin'd to the great; but it will descend, and in a couple of months I shall not be surpriz'd to hear an attorney's hackney-clerk rousing at midnight a millener's prentice, with an "Ally, Ally Croker." But that, if I mistake not, is the temple; and see—my goddess herself. Miss Godfrey!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Hush.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Am I right, Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Softly. You receiv'd my letter, I see, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: And flew to the appointment with more—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: No raptures, I beg. But you must not suppose this meeting meant to encourage your hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: How, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh, by no means, Sir; for tho' I own your figure is pleasing, and your conversation—

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Hold, Miss; when did I ever con∣verse with him?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Why, did not you see him in the Park?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: True, Madam; but the conversation was with you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Bless me! you are very difficult. I say, Sir, though your person may be unexcep∣tionable, yet your character—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: My character!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Come, come, you are better known than you imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Your name is Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: How the deuce came she by that! True, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Pray have you never heard of a Miss Grantam?

SP.SPEAKER: Y Wild.
SP.P: Frequently.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: You have. And had you never any favourable thoughts of that lady? Now mind, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: If you mean as a lover, never. The lady did me the honour to have a small design upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: M God.
SP.P: I hear every word, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: But you need not lean so heavy upon me; he speaks loud enough to be heard.—I have been told, Sir, that—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am, and very possibly by the lady herself.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, madam, I have another obliga∣tion in my pocket to Miss Grantam, which must be discharg'd in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: M Gr.
SP.P: Of what kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: Why the lady, finding an old hum∣ble servant of hers a little lethargic, has thought sit to administer me in a jealous draught, in or∣der to quicken his passion.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Sir, let me tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Have a care; you will betray your∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, the whole story will afford you infinite diversion: such a farago of fights and feasts. But, upon my honour, the girl has a fertile invention.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: So! what that story was yours, was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, don't I hear another voice?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: A distant relation of mine.—Every syllable false.—But, Sir, we have another charge against you. Do you know any thing of a lady at Abingon.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Miss Grantam again. Yes, Madam, I have some knowledge of that lady.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: You have! Well, Sir, and that being the case, how could you have the assurance—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A moment's patience, Ma'am. That lady, that Berkshire lady, will, I can assure you, prove no bar to my hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: How, Sir! no bar?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Not in the least, Ma'am; for that lady exists in idea only.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: No such person!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: A mere creature of the imagination.

SP.SPEAKER: M Gr
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The attacks of Miss Grantam were so powerfully enforc'd too by paternal authori∣ty, that I had no method of avoiding the blow, but by the sheltering myself under this conjugal shield.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: You are not marry'd then?—But what credit can I give to the professions of a man, who, in an article of such importance, and to a person of such respect—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Nay, Madam, surely Miss Godfrey should not accuse me of a crime her own charms have occasion'd. Could any other motive but the fear of losing her prevail on me to trifle with a father, or compel me to infringe those laws which I have hitherto so inviolably observ'd?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: What laws, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The sacred laws of truth, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: There, indeed, you did yourself an infinite violence But when the whole of the af∣fair is discover'd, will it be so easy to get rid of Miss Grantam? the violence of her passion, and the old gentleman's obstinacy—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Are nothing to a mind resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Poor Miss Grantam!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Do you know her, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: I have heard of her: but you, Sir, I suppose, have been long on an intimate footing?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Bred up together from children.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Brave!—Is she handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Y Wild.
SP.P: Her paint comes from Paris, and her femme de chambre is an excellent artist.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Very well!—Her shape?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, is not Curson esteem'd the best stay-maker for people inclin'd to be crooked?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: But as to the qualities of her mind: for instance, her understanding?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Uncultivated.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Her wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Borrow'd.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Her taste?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Trifling.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: And her temper?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: Intolerable.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr
SP.P: A finish'd picture. But come, these are not your real thoughts; this is a sacrifice you think due to the vanity of our sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: My honest sentiments: and to con∣vince you how thoroughly indifferent I am to that lady, I would, upon my veracity, as soon take a wife from the grand senior's seraglio.—Now, Ma'am, I hope you are satisfy'd

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: And you would not scruple to ac∣knowledge this before the lady's face?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: The first opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: That I will take care to provide you. Dare you meet me at her house?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: When?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: In half-an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But won't a declaration of this sort appear odd at—a—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Come, no evasion; your conduct and character seem to me a little equivocal, and I must insist on this proof at least of—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You shall have it.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: In half-an-hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: This instant.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Be punctual.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Or may I forfeit your favour.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Very well: till then, Sir, adieu.—Now I think I have my spark in the toil; and if the fellow has any feeling, if I don't make him smart for every article—Come, my dear, I shall stand in need of your aid.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: So! I am now, I think, arriv'd at a critical period. If I can but weather this point—But why should I doubt it? it is in the day of distress only that a great man displays his abilities. But I shall want Papillion: where can the puppy be?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: So, Sir; where have you been ram∣bling?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: I did not suppose you would want—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Want!—You are always out of the way: Here have I been forc'd to tell forty lies upon my own credit, and not a single soul to vouch for the truth of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Don't plague me with your apolo∣gies: but it is lucky for you that I want your assistance. Come with me to Miss Grantam's.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: On what occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: An important one: but I'll prepare you as we walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Sir, I am really—I could wish you would be so good as to—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What, desert your friend in the heat of battle! oh, you poltroon!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Sir, I would do any thing; but you know I have not talents.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I do; and for my own sake shall not task them too high.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Now I suppose the hour is come when we shall pay for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, what a dastardly, hen-hearted—But come, Papillion, this shall be your last campaign. Don't droop, man; confide in your leader, and remember, Sub auspice Teucro nil desperandum.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE a Room.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter a SERVANT, conducting in OLD WILDING.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My lady, Sir, will be at home imme∣diately. Sir James Elliot is in the next room, waiting her return.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Pray, honest friend, will you tell Sir James that I beg the favour of a word with him. [Exit Servant.] This unthinking boy! Half the purpose of my life has been to plan this scheme for his happiness, and in one heed∣less hour has he mangled all.
Sir, I ask your pardon; but upon so interesting a subject, I know you will excuse my intrusion. Pray, Sir, of what credit is the family of the Sybthorpes in Berkshire?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I don't mean as to property; that I am not so solicitous about; but as to their cha∣racter: Do they live in reputation? are they re∣spected in the neighbourhood?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: The family of the Sybthorpes!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Of the Sybthorpes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Really I don't know, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Not know!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: No; it is the very first time I ever heard of the name.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: How steadily he denies it! well done, baronet! I find Jack's account was a just one. [Aside.] Pray, Sir James, recollect yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: It will be to no purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Come, Sir, your motive for this af∣fected ignorance is a generous, but unnecessary proof of your friendship for my son: but I know the whole affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: What affair?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Jack's marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: What Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: My son Jack.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Is he marry'd?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Is he marry'd! why you know he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Not I, upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Nay, that is going a little too far: but, to remove all your scruples at once, he has own'd it himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: He has.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Ay, ay, to me. Every circumstance: Going to your new purchase at Abington—meet∣ing Lydia Sybthorpe at an assembly—their pri∣vate interviews—surpriz'd by the father—pistol—poker—and marriage; in short, every parti∣cular.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: And this account you had from your son?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: From Jack; not two hours ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I wish you joy, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Not much of that, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Why, Sir, does the marriage displease you?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Doubtless.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Then I fancy you may make yourself easy.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: You have got, Sir, the most prudent daughter-in-law in the British dominions.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I am happy to hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
