SP.P: For though she mayn't have brought you much, I'm sure she'll not cost you a farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Ay; exactly Jack's account.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: She'll be easily jointur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Justice shall be done her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: No provision necessary for younger children.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: No Sir! why not?—I can tell you, if she answers your account, not the daughter of a duke—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You are merry, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: What an unaccountable fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, Sir. But with re∣gard to this marriage—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I take the whole history to be neither more nor less than an absolute fable.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: How, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Even so.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why, Sir, do you think my son would dare to impose upon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Sir, he would dare to impose upon any body. Don't I know him?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What do you know?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I know, Sir, that his narratives gain him more applause than credit; and that, whe∣ther from constitution or habit, there is no be∣lieving a syllable he says.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, mighty well, Sir!—He wants to turn the tables upon Jack.—But it won't do; you are forestall'd; your novels won't pass upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Nor is the character of my son to be blasted by the breath of a bouncer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: What is this?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: No, no, Mr. Mandeville, it won't do; you are as well known here as in your own county of Hereford.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Mr. Wilding, but that I am sure this extravagant behaviour owes its rise to some im∣pudent impositions of your son, your age would scarce prove your protection.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Nor, Sir, but that I know my boy equal to the defence of his own honour, should he want a protector in this arm, wither'd and impotent as you may think it.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Bless me, Gentlemen, what is the meaning of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: No more at present, Sir: I have an∣other demand upon your son; we'll settle the whole together.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I am sure he will do you justice.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: How, Sir James Elliot! I flatter'd myself that you had finish'd your visits here, Sir. Must I be the eternal object of your outrage? not only insulted in my own person, but in that of my friends! Pray, Sir, what right—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Madam, I ask your pardon; a dis∣agreeable occasion brought me here: I come, Madam, to renounce all hopes of being nearer ally'd to you, my son unfortunately being mar∣ry'd already.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Marry'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, to a lady in the clouds; and because I have refus'd to acknowledge her family, this old gentleman has behav'd in a manner very inconsistent with his usual po∣liteness.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Sir, I thought this affair was to be reserv'd for another occasion; but you, it seems—

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Oh, is that the business?—Why, I begin to be afraid that we are here a little in the wrong, Mr. Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Your son has just confirm'd Sir James Elliot's opinion, at a conference under Miss Godfrey's window.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Most true; and assign'd two most whimsical motives for the unaccountable tale.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What can they be?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: An aversion for me, whom he has seen but once, and an affection for Miss God∣frey, whom I am almost sure he never saw in his life.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You amaze me.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Indeed, Mr. Wilding, your son is a most extraordinary youth; he has finely perplex'd us all. I think, Sir James, you have a small ob∣ligation to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: Which I shall take care to acknow∣ledge the first opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You have my consent. An aban∣don'd profligate! was his father a proper subject for his—But I discard him.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Nay, now, Gentlemen, you are rather too warm: I can't think Mr. Wilding bad-hearted at the bottom. This is a levity—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: How, Madam! a levity!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Take my word for it, no more; en∣flam'd into habit by the approbation of his juve∣nile friends. Will you submit his punishment to me? I think I have the means in my hands, both to satisfy your resentments, and accomplish his cure into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ja.
SP.P: I have no quarrel to him, but for the ill offices he has done me with you.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: D'ye hear, Mr. Wilding? I am afraid my union with Sir James must cement the ge∣neral peace.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Madam, I submit to any—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Wilding to wait upon you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: He is punctual, I ind. Come, good folks, you all act under my direction. You, Sir, will get from your son, by what means you think fit, the real truth of the Abington busi∣ness. You must likewise seemingly consent to his marriage with Miss Godfrey, who I shrewdly suspect he has by some odd accident mistaken for me: The lady herself shall appear at your call. Come, Sir James, you will withdraw. I intend to produce another performer, who will want a little instruction. Kitty.

Let John shew Mr. Wilding in to his father; then come to my dressing-room: I have a short scene to give you in study. [Exit Kitty.] The girl is lively, and, I warrant, will do her cha∣racter justice. Come, Sir James. Nay, no ce∣remony; we must be as busy as bees.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: This strange boy!—But I must com∣mand my temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: People to speak with me! See what they want Papillion.—My father here! that's unlucky enough.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Ha, Jack! what brings you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, Sir, I thought it my duty to wait upon Miss Grantam, in order to make her some apology for the late unfortunate—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Well now, that is prudently as well as politely done.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I am happy to meet, Sir, with your approbation.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I have been thinking, Jack, about my daughter-in-law: as the affair is public, it is not decent to let her continue longer at her father's.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Would it not be right to send for her home?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Doubtless, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I think so. Why then to-morrow my chariot shall fetch her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The devil it shall! [Aside.] Not quite so soon, if you please, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: No! why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The journey may be dangerous in her present condition.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What's the matter with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: She is big with child, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: An audacious—Big with child! that is fortunate. But, however, an easy car∣riage, and short stages, can't hurt her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir, I dare not trust her: she is six months gone.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Nay, then there may be danger in∣deed. But should not I write to her father, just to let him know that you have discovered the secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: By all means, Sir: it will make him extremely happy.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Why then I will instantly about it. Pray, how do you direct to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Abington, Berkshire.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: True; but his address?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You need not trouble yourself, Sir▪ I shall write by this post to my wife, and will send your letter inclos'd.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Ay, ay, that will do.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: So, I have parry'd that thrust.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Tho', upon second thoughts, Jack, that will rather look too familiar for an intro∣ductory letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And these country-gentlemen are so full of punctilios—No, I'll send him a letter apart; so give me his direction.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You have it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Ay, but his name: I have been so hurry'd that I have entirely forgot it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I am sure so have I. [Aside.] His name—his name, Sir—Hopkins.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Hopkins!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: That is not the same name that you gave me before: that, if I recollect, was either Sypthorpe or Sybthorpe.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: You are right, Sir; that is his pa∣ternal appellation; but the name of Hopkins he took for an estate of his mother's: so he is indiscriminately called Hopkins or Sybthorpe; and now I recollect I have his letter in my poc∣ket—he signs himself Sybthorpe Hopkins.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: There is no end of this: I must stop him at once. Harkye, Sir, I think you are call'd my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, you have no reason to doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And look upon yourself as a gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: In having the honour of descending from you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And that you think a sufficient pre∣tension?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir—pray, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And by what means do you imagine your ancestors obtain'd that distinguishing title? By their pre-eminence in virtue, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Doubtless, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And has it never occurr'd to you, that what was gain'd by honour might be lost by infamy?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Perfectly, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Are you to learn what redress even the imputation of a lye demands, and that no∣thing less than the life of the adversary can ex∣tinguish the affront?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Doubtless, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Then how dare you call yourself a gentleman? you, whose whole life has been one continued scene of fraud and falsity! And would nothing content you but making me a partner in your infamy? not satisfied with vio∣lating that great band of society, mutual con∣fidence, the most sacred rights of nature must be invaded, and your father made the innocent instru∣ment to circulate your abominable impositions!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Within this hour my life was near sa∣crific'd in defence of your fame: But perhaps that was your intention, and the story of your marriage merely calculated to send me out of the world, as a grateful return for my bringing you into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O Wild.
SP.P: What other motive?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Hear me, I intreat you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: To be again impos'd on! no, Jack, my eyes are open'd at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: By all that's sacred, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I am now deaf to your delusions.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But hear me, Sir. I own the Abing∣ton business—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: An absolute fiction?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And how dare you—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I crave but a moment's audience.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Previous to the communication of your intention for me, I accidentally met with a lady whose charms—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: So! what, here's another marriage trumped out: but that is a stale device. And pray, Sir, what place does this lady inhabit? Come, come, go on; you have a fertile inven∣tion, and this is a fine opportunity. Well, Sir, and this charming lady, residing, I suppose, in Nubibus—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No, Sir; in London.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Nay more, and at this instant in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And her name—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Godfrey.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: The friend of Miss Grantam?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The very same, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Have you spoke to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Parted from her not ten minutes ago; nay, am here by her appointment.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Has she favour'd your address?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Time, Sir, and your approbation will, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P:
Lookye, Sir; as there is some little probability in this story, I shall think it worth
farther enquiry. To be plain with you, I know Miss Godsrey; am intimate with her family; and though you deserve but little from me, I will endeavour to aid your intention. But if, in the progress of this affair, you practise any of your usual arts; if I discover the least falshood, the least duplicity, remember you have lost a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: I shall submit without a murmur.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Well, Papillion.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Sir, here has been the devil to pay within.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: A whole legion of cooks, confectioners, musicians, waiters, and watermen.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What do they want?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: You, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Me!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; they have brought in their bills.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Bills! for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: For the entertainment you gave last night upon the water.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: That I gave!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; you remember the bill of fare: I am sure the very mention of it makes my mouth water.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Prithee, are you mad? There must be some mistake; you know that I—

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: They have been vastly puzzled to find out your lodgings; but Mr Robinson meeting by accident with Sir James Elliot, he was kind enough to tell him where you liv'd. Here are the bills: Almack's, twelve dozen of claret, ditto Champagne, Frontiniac, sweetmeats, pine-ap∣ples: the whole amount is 372 l 9 s▪ besides music and fireworks.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Come, Sir, this is no time for trifling.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, they say they have gone full as low as they can afford; and they were in hopes, from the great satisfaction you express'd to Sir James Elliot, that you would throw them in an additional compliment.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Harkye, Mr. Papillion, if you don't cease your impertinence, I shall pay you a com∣pliment that you would gladly excuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Upon my faith, I relate but the mere matter of fact. You know, Sir, I am but bad at invention; tho' this incident I can't help think∣ing is the natural fruit of your happy one.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: But are you serious? is this possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Most certain. It was with difficulty I restrain'd their impatience; but however I have dispatch'd them to your lodgings, with a promise that you shall immediately meet them.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Oh, there we shall soon rid our hands of the troop—Now, Papillion, I have news for you. My father has got to the bottom of the whole Abington business.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: The deuce!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: We parted this moment. Such a scene!

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And what was the issue?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild
SP.P: Happy beyond my hopes. Not only an act of oblivion, but a promise to plead my cause with the fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: With Miss Godfrey?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Who else?—He is now with her in another room.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: And there is no—you understand me—in all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No, no; that is all over now—my reformation is fix'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: As a weather-cock.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Here comes my father.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I find in this last article you have condescended to tell me the truth: the young lady is not averse to your union; but in order to fix so mutable a mind, I have drawn up a slight contract which you are both to sign.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: With transport.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: I will introduce Miss Godfrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Did not I tell you, Papillion?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: This is amazing, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Am not I a happy fortunate?—But they come.
SP.STAGE: Enter OLD WILDING and Miss GODFREY.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: If, Madam, he has not the highest sense of the great honour you do him, I shall cease to regard him,—There, Sir, make your own acknowledgments to that lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: This is more than you merit; but let your future behaviour testify your gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Papillion! Madam! Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What, is the puppy petrified! Why don't you go up to the lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Up to the lady!—That lady?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: That lady!—To be sure. What other lady?—To Miss Godfrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: That lady Miss Godfrey!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What is all this?—Harkye, Sir: I see what you are at: But no trifling; I'll be no more the dupe of your double detestable—Re∣collect my last resolution: this instant your hand to the contract, or tremble at the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir, that I hope is—might not I—to be sure—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: No further evasions! There, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Heigh ho!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Very well. Now, Madam, your name, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Papillion, do you know who she is?

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: That's a question, indeed! Don't you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Not I, as I hope to be sav'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: A young lady begs to speak with Mr. Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: With me!

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: A young lady with Mr. Wilding!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Seems distress'd, Madam; and extremely pressing for admittance.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Indeed! There may be something in this!—You must permit me, Sir, to pause a lit∣tle; who knows but a prior claim may prevent—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: How, Sir! who is this lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: It is impossible for me to divine, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You know nothing of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: How should I?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You hear, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: I presume your son can have no ob∣jection to the lady's appearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Not in the least, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Shew her in, John.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: No, Madam, I don't think there is the least room for suspecting him; he can't be so abandoned as to—But she is here. Upon my word, a sightly woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Where is he?—Oh, let me rhrow my arms—My life, my—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Heyday!

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: And could you leave me? and for so long a space! Think how the tedious time has lagg'd along.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: But we are met at last, and now will part no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: The deuce we won't!

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: What, not one kind look, no tender word, to hail our second meeting!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: What the devil is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Are all your oaths, your protestations, come to this? have I deserv'd such treatment? Quitted my father's house, left all my friends, and wander'd here alone in search of thee, thou first, last, only object of my love.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: To what can all this tend? Harkye, Sir, unriddle this mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Davus, non Oedipus sum. It is be∣yond me, I confess. Some lunatic escap'd from her keeper, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Am I disown'd then, contemn'd, slighted?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Hold; let me enquire into this mat∣ter a little. Pray, Madam—You seem to be pretty familiar here—Do you know this gen∣tleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Too well.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: His name?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: So far she is right. Now yours, if you please?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Wilding!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: And how came you by that name, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Most lawfully, Sir: By the sacred band, the holy tie, that made us one.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What, marry'd to him!

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Most true.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Sir, may I never—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild
SP.P: Peace, Monster!—One question more: Your maiden name?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Sybthorpe.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Lydia, from Abington in the couny of Berks?

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: The same.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: As I suspected. So then the whole story is true, and the monster is marry'd at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Me, Sir! By all that's—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Eternal dumbness seize thee, measure∣less lyar!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: If not me, hear this gentleman.—Marquis—

SP.SPEAKER: Pap.
SP.P: Not I; I'll be drawn into none of your scrapes: it is a pit of your own digging, and so get out as well as you can. Mean time, I'll shift for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: What evasion now, Monster?

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Deceiver!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Lyar!

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Impostor!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Why, this is a general combination to distract me: but I will be heard. Sir, you are grosly impos'd upon: the low contriver of this woman's shallow artifice I shall soon find means to discover; and as to you, Madam, with whom I have been suddenly surpriz'd into a con∣tract, I most solemnly declare this is the first time I ever sat eyes on you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Amazing confidence! Did not I bring her at your own request?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Is not this your own letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Am not I your wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Did not you own it to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: Yes—that is—no, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Kitty.
SP.P: Hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: M. God.
SP.P: Answer me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Wild.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: Have not I—

SP.SPEAKER: Y Wild.
SP.P: No, no, no. Zounds, you are all mad, and if I stay I shall catch the infection.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir JAMES ELLIOT and Miss GRANTAM.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: Finely perform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: You have kept your promise, and I thank you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.P: My medicine was somewhat rough, Sir; but in desperate cases, you know—

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.P: If his cure is compleated, he will gratefully acknowledge the cause; if not, the punishment comes far short of his crimes. It is needless to pay you any compliments, Sir James; with that lady you can't fail to be happy. I shan't venture to hint a scheme I have greatly at heart, till we have undeniable proofs of the suc∣cess of our operations. To the ladies, indeed, no character is so dangerous as that of a lyar.
SP.L: They in the fairest fames can fix a flaw,
And vanquish females whom they never saw.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: Between Miss GRANTAM and OLD WILDING. By a Man of Fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.L: HOLD, Sir.
Our plot concluded, and strict justice done,
Let me be heard as counsel for your son.
Acquit I can't; I mean to mitigate:
Proscribe all lying, what would be the fate
Of this and every other earthly state?
Consider, Sir, if once you cry it down,
You'll shut up ev'ry coffee-house in town:
The tribe of politicians will want food;
Ev'n now half-famish'd—for the public good.
All Grubstreet murderers of men and sense,
And every office of intelligence,
All would be bankrupts, the whole lying race,
And no Gazette to publish their disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.L: Too mild a sentence! must the good and great
Patriots be wrong'd, that booksellers may eat?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.L: Your patience, Sir; yet hear another word.
Turn to that hall where justice wields her sword:
Think in what narrow limits you would draw,
By this proscription, all the sons of law:
For 'tis the fix'd, determin'd rule of courts,
Vynr will tel you, nay, even Coke's Reports,
All pleaders may, when difficulties rise,
To gain one truth, expend a hundred lyes.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.L: To curb this practice I am somewhat loath;
A lawyer has no credit but on oath.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.L: Then to the softer sex some favour shew:
Leave no possession of our modest No!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.L: Oh, freely, Ma'am, we'll that allow∣ance give,
So that two Noes be held affirmative.
Providd ever, that your pish and fie,
On all occasions, should be deem'd a lye.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.L: Hard terms!
On this rejoinder then I rest my cause;
Should all pay homage to Truth's sacred laws,
Let us examine what would be the case:
Why, many a great man would be out of place.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.L: 'Twould many a virtuous character restore.

SP.SPEAKER: M Gr.
SP.L: But take a character from many more.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Wild.
SP.L: Tho' on the side of bad the ballance fall,
Better to find few good, than fear for all.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gr.
SP.L: Strong are your reasons; yet, ere I submit,
I mean to take the voices of the pit.
Is it your pleasures that we make a rule,
That ev'ry lyar be proclaim'd a fool,
Fit subjects for our author's ridicule?
